bookinfo.title: Univention Corporate Server
bookinfo.subtitle: Quick start guide for Univention Corporate Server

chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Univention Corporate Server (UCS) is a server operating system based on Debian with integrated management system for the central administration of servers, services, clients, desktops and users.

This quickstart guide offers a short introduction on how to get started with UCS. Several featues of UCS are only mentioned briefly with a reference to further documentation. The documention on UCS is available at .

The installation DVD can be downloaded from the Univention website at . Installation DVDs are available for the amd64 (64-bit) and i386 (32-bit) CPU architectures. The installation of the 64 bit version is recommended.
Alternatively preinstalled images for VMWare and VirtualBox can be used. These are available for download at ..

An ISO DVD image for amd64 with support for the Unified Extensible Firmware Interface-Standard (UEFI) is available besides the default installation DVD. On systems that support only a UEFI start, it must be used instead of the default DVD.
The system requirements vary considerably depending on the intended purpose and the number of users. The minimum requirements for the installation are 512 MB memory and 8 GB hard drive space.

chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para: The installation is performed via a menu-driven text installer and can be used both interactively and completely profile-based .
The system language, keyboard layout and time zone can be selected in accordance with local requirements.

The &ucsMaster; is always the first system of a UCS domain, it should be selected as the system role. All other system join the UCS domain during the installation. An overview of the additional system roles can be found in the UCS manual .

The fully qualified domain name of the &ucsUCS; system under which the computer should be accessible in the network should be entered under Fully qualified domain name (e.g., mail.example.com). A non-public domain name can be chosen here, e.g. company.local. (If the system is to be used as mail server the mail domains can be selected independently of the domain name). The LDAP base and the Windows domain are suggested based on the complete computer name and only need to be adjusted in exceptional cases. The root password must be at least eight characters long and is also set as the password for the Administrator user during the installation of the first UCS server (&ucsMaster;).

An autopartitioning feature can be used during the installation which creates an LVM partion on the first hard drive by default. If hard drive encryption or software RAID is to be used, the installation must be performed in expert mode. This is documented in the extended installation documentation . When using RAID, a hardware controller is recommended.

A valid network configuration should be set during the installation. If, for example, a gateway and a name server are specified, but the name server cannot be reached, this may result in unnecessary timeouts. In these cases, it makes more sense not to specify a gateway. The network configuration can be employed using DHCP, e.g. if UCS is used on a cloud provider without a static IP address.
The installed software components can be adapted later at any time and subsequently installed from the Univention App Center.
After confirming the configuration settings the installation is initiated. Once completed, the system must be restarted. The further configuration is made using the &ucsUMC; (UMC).

chapter.title: Administration (Univention Management Console)
chapter.para: The installed UCS system is configured via the web-based &ucsUMC; (reachable at https://server_ip or http://server_ip, HTTPS is recommended) which be reached under System and domain settings. The login to the &ucsUMC; is performed as the Administrator with the password specified for the root user during the installation.

&ucsUMC; (UMC) is the central tool for web-based administration of the UCS domain. UMC supports two basic module types:
Domain modules manage all the data saved in the LDAP directory, e.g., users, groups or host accounts. All the modifications made here apply to the whole domain and are automatically replicated to all further LDAP servers. Domain modules are only displayed on the &ucsMaster; and &ucsBackup;. All the domain modules can also be controlled with a command line interface, the &ucsUDM; .
System modules allow the configuration or management of an individual system, e.g., the starting or stopping of services or the installation of software from the Univention App Center.
Users, groups, computers, etc., can only be managed on the &ucsMaster; (the first system of the UCS domain). The data are automatically distributed to the other servers in the UCS domain.
The administration of individual systems (such as updates, software installations and configuration adjustments) are also performed via the &ucsUMC; (or alternatively through command line tools).

chapter.title: UCS updates / Installing additional software
chapter.para: UCS updates can be installed in the UMC module Software update.

Additional software can be installed using the Univention App Center in the Univention Management Console:
Additional UCS software can be installed/removed using the category UCS components.
Third-party software (e.g. various groupware solutions) and UCS-compatible addon products (e.g. UCS@school for school deployment can also be installed through the App Center.

chapter.title: Configuration management using Univention Configuration Registry
chapter.para: Univention Configuration Registry is the central tool for managing the local system configuration of a UCS system. Settings are specified in a consistent format, the so-called Univention Configuration Registry variables. These variables are used to generate the configuration files used effectively by the services/programs. Direct editing of the configuration files is only needed in exceptional cases.
&ucsUCR; variables are managed via the &ucsUMC; module Univention Configuration Registry. Configuration files are automatically updated when the UCR variables registered on them are changed.

chapter.title: Clients
chapter.para:
In addition to the UCS servers, a UCS domain can also integrate different clients. The following clients are supported:
Windows clients can join an AD-compatible Windows domain provided by the Active Directory compatible domain controller component (implemented using the software Samba). Further information on setting up Samba and the domain join of Windows clients can be found in the UCS manual .
Mac OS X systems are also integrated via a Samba-based, AD-compatible Windows domain. Further information on setting up Samba and the domain join of Windows clients can be found in the UCS manual .
Univention Corporate Client can be installed from the Univention App Center for the deployment of centrally administrated Linux-based desktop. Further information can be found in the UCC manual .
Ubuntu systems and other Linux distributions like Debian, SuSE or Red Hat can also be integrated into the domain .

chapter.title: Further expansion of the domain
chapter.para: This quickstart guide only provides an entry into UCS. UCS is very scalable, additional services can simply be installed on additional systems. This domain join is described in .

UCS offers various additional services which are covered by the UCS license and which can be integrated at a later point in time:
Single-sign-on with web services using a SAML identity provider
IP management using DHCP
Web proxy for caching and policy management / virus scan
Service monitoring with Nagios
Virtualisation with KVM / Xen
